summary: Email correspondence between attorneys Brad Edwards and Paul Cassell and a U.S. Attorney's Office representative regarding the drafting of a protective order for the disclosure of the non-prosecution agreement in the Jeffrey Epstein case. The emails discuss language revisions to ensure compliance with a court ruling by Judge Marra while allowing petitioners' counsel to share the agreement with their clients under specific conditions.

persons.name: Brad Edwards
persons.context: Attorney representing petitioners in the Epstein case, corresponding with the U.S. Attorney's Office and co-counsel Paul Cassell about finalizing a protective order for the non-prosecution agreement.

persons.name: Paul Cassell
persons.role: Attorney for petitioners, Professor of Law
persons.context: Co-counsel for petitioners, corresponding with the U.S. Attorney's Office and Brad Edwards to revise the protective order language, emphasizing the need to share the non-prosecution agreement with clients promptly due to Epstein's alleged non-compliance.

persons.name: Judge Marra
persons.context: Judge who issued a ruling referenced in the emails, which the protective order is intended to cover.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Subject of the non-prosecution agreement, referenced as allegedly trying to ignore the agreement, prompting urgency in finalizing the protective order.

connections.description: Co-counsels representing petitioners in the Epstein case, collaborating on drafting and negotiating the protective order with the U.S. Attorney's Office.
Corresponding to finalize the protective order, with Edwards agreeing to submit the government's proposed order despite some disagreements.
Negotiating language changes to the protective order, with Cassell proposing revisions to allow counsel to share the non-prosecution agreement with clients under specific conditions.
Cassell references Epstein as allegedly trying to ignore the non-prosecution agreement, prompting urgency in finalizing the protective order for disclosure to clients.

events.title: Judge Marra's ruling on protective order
events.description: Judge Marra issued a ruling referenced in the emails, which the protective order is intended to cover thoroughly.

events.title: Finalization of protective order draft
events.description: Email correspondence finalizing the draft protective order for the disclosure of the non-prosecution agreement, with revisions proposed by Paul Cassell.

locations: University of Utah S. J. Quinney College of Law
keyFacts: The U.S. Attorney's Office and petitioners' attorneys are finalizing a protective order for the disclosure of the non-prosecution agreement in the Epstein case.

Paul Cassell proposes language changes to allow petitioners' counsel to share the non-prosecution agreement with their clients under specific conditions, citing urgency due to Epstein allegedly trying to ignore the agreement.
The protective order is intended to cover Judge Marra's ruling from the previous day, with disagreements noted on the scope of the order.
The correspondence highlights legal maneuvering to balance disclosure to victims with protective measures, reflecting ongoing tensions in the Epstein case in August 2008.
